notes.text:
A vulnerability in the web framework of Cisco Prime Collaboration Provisioning  could allow an
authenticated, remote attacker to access higher-privileged functions.



An exploit could
allow the attacker to access functions, some of which should be accessible only to users who have administrative privileges. This includes creating an administrative user.



Cisco has released software updates that address this vulnerability. Workarounds that mitigate this vulnerability are not available.
This advisory is available at the following link:

http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20150916-pcp["http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20150916-pcp"]
notes.title: Summary

notes.text: Any product running a vulnerable version of Cisco Prime Collaboration Provisioning Software is affected by this vulnerability.
notes.title: Vulnerable Products

notes.text:
Cisco Prime Collaboration Assurance is not affected by this
vulnerability; however, a different access controls bypass vulnerability has been found in Cisco Prime
Collaboration Assurance, which is disclosed in the Multiple Vulnerabilities in Cisco Prime Collaboration Assurance security
advisory at the following link:

http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20150916-pca

["http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20150916-pca"]


No other Cisco products are currently known to be affected by this vulnerability.
notes.title: Products Confirmed Not Vulnerable

notes.text:
Cisco Prime Collaboration helps enable rapid installation and maintenance
of Cisco Unified Communications and Cisco TelePresence components as
well as the provisioning of users and services.



A vulnerability in the web framework of Cisco Prime Collaboration Provisioning  could allow an
authenticated, remote attacker to access higher-privileged functions.



The
vulnerability is due to improper implementation of authorization and
access controls. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending
a crafted URL to the system. The attacker would need to be logged in to
the system to exploit this vulnerability.



An exploit could
allow the attacker to access functions, some of which should be accessible only
to users who have administrative privileges.
Because of this vulnerability, an attacker may be able to create an
additional administrative user and access or manipulate data.



This vulnerability is documented in Cisco bug ID CSCut64111["https://bst.cloudapps.cisco.com/bugsearch/bug/CSCut64111"] (registered["http://tools.cisco.com/RPF/register/register.do"] customers only) and has been assigned Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) ID CVE-2015-4307.
notes.title: Details

notes.text: There is no workaround that mitigates this vulnerability.
notes.title: Workarounds

notes.text:
When considering software upgrades, customers are advised to consult the Cisco Security Advisories, Responses, and Alerts archive at http://www.cisco.com/go/psirt["http://www.cisco.com/go/psirt"] and review subsequent advisories to determine exposure and a complete upgrade solution. 

In all cases, customers should ensure that the devices to be upgraded contain sufficient memory and  confirm that current hardware and software configurations will continue to be supported properly by the new release. If the information is not clear, customers are advised to contact the Cisco Technical Assistance Center (TAC) or their contracted maintenance providers. 

This vulnerability has been resolved in Cisco Prime Collaboration Provisioning Software Release 11.0 and later.
notes.title: Fixed Software

notes.text: To learn about Cisco security vulnerability disclosure policies and publications, see the Security Vulnerability Policy[http://www.cisco.com/web/about/security/psirt/security_vulnerability_policy.html]. This document also contains instructions for obtaining fixed software and receiving security vulnerability information from Cisco.
notes.title: Vulnerability Policy

notes.text:
The Cisco Product Security Incident Response Team (PSIRT) is not aware of any public announcements or malicious use of the vulnerability that is described in this advisory. 

This vulnerability has been found during internal security tests.
notes.title: Exploitation and Public Announcements

notes.text:

publisher.issuing_authority:
Cisco product security incident response is the responsibility of the Cisco Product Security Incident Response Team (PSIRT). The Cisco PSIRT is a dedicated, global team that manages the receipt, investigation, and public reporting of security vulnerability information that is related to Cisco products and networks. The on-call Cisco PSIRT works 24x7 with Cisco customers, independent security researchers, consultants, industry organizations, and other vendors to identify possible security issues with Cisco products and networks.
More information can be found in Cisco Security Vulnerability Policy available at http://www.cisco.com/web/about/security/psirt/security_vulnerability_policy.html
publisher.name: Cisco
